deployment/ceph-ansible/ceph-base.yaml.message: seems like a big change in the default is it really necessary? I wonder if it will surprise someone but i guess, there *will* have to be special preparations made anyway if you are going from something deployed with ceph-ansible to now deployed/upgraded with cephadm

If you have an existing cluster, then this change shouldn't affect you so it doesn't affect upgrades. It affects new deployments. We also have a release note for this. The 128 value has caused more harm than good with new deployments so changing this default and using the auto scaler is a user experience improvement.

Hey Marios thank you for the question. This change comes from a new default in Ceph, which is related to the pg_autoscaling [1].
Since pg_autoscale is enabled by default, there's no reason for tuning PG_* parameters anymore, unless there's a specific need; this means that when a pool is created the pg_autoscaler is enabled by default, but you can still specify this parameter which is now lower to make the CI and even small (or any all-in-one) deployments happy.
By doing this, you can start from a low default pg number, which will be automatically increased by the autoscaler module (and no risk of ending up with some sort of pg overflow [_too many PGs per OSD_]).
This change is also valid for both nautilus and octopus, and when a stack update is running against an existing environment, there's no action performed from ceph-ansible on the existing pools, so it's safe enough.
With respect to a potential upgrade scenario, ceph-ansible is able to gather facts from the existing cluster and afaik the impact is only for the deployed daemons, hence pools are not touched (I'm pretty sure it's the same for the adoption process [2], which happens after the upgrade from ceph4 to ceph5 using [3]) 

[1] https://ceph.io/rados/new-in-nautilus-pg-merging-and-autotuning/
[2] https://github.com/ceph/ceph-ansible/blob/master/infrastructure-playbooks/cephadm-adopt.yml
[3] https://github.com/ceph/ceph-ansible/blob/master/infrastructure-playbooks/rolling_update.yml
so you probably want to move that comment down to include the CephOsdPercentageMin?
is it deprecated or 'no longer has any effect do not use this'

This parameter is used here [1] and it's required by the ceph-health validation. This should be 0 for cephadm and tht (or can be even removed), and to have params consistency between the two branches (cephadm vs ceph-ansible) [2] we need the same parameter and the same defaults everywhere (or at least I'm not sure how to define the same parameter in different tht w/ different default values ... not sure this is possible).
Since master/W+ is going to deploy (by default) Ceph using cephadm, the idea is to keep all the involved parameters, and mark them as deprecated and remove them on the X cycle.
Operators and CI jobs can still override that parameter if needed, but since the status of the Ceph cluster is maintained within ceph orchestrator, this parameter shouldn't be needed anymore.  


[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/ceph-ansible/ceph-base.yaml#L730
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/767294/57/tools/yaml-validate.py

add your new deprecations here 

this stuff is picked up by tripleoclient and operator gets a warning about using deprecated parameters https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/src/commit/42aa7357fb59ebad2ef34108fa1ad3e259b10cb6/tripleoclient/workflows/parameters.py#L166

Hi Marios,

I think Francesco has taken care of this by adding CephOsdPercentageMin to the deprecated list on line 357 in patch set 58. 

If you want some extra details though here they are. We're deprecating different types of things: deployment methods (ceph-ansible in favor of cephadm), files used during deployment (deployment/ceph-ansible/* in favor of deployment/cephadm/*), and parameters. There are parameters, used by both deployment methods, which deprecate depending on which method is being used so we have a separate list for each. If you deploy with cephadm, then we have a list of deprecated parameters [1] to warn about. If you deploy with ceph-ansible, then we have another list of deprecated parameters [2] to warn about. Having different lists was deliberate. We aim to remove the ceph-ansible deployment method in X and deprecate it in W. So if you're using the deprecated ceph-ansible method in W, then you get a different warning. However, per the release note you should also know that the ceph-ansible method is deprecated. In the end (X) it ends up being one list of deprecated parameters though regardless of method.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/767294/58/deployment/cephadm/ceph-base.yaml#326

[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/767294/58/deployment/ceph-ansible/ceph-base.yaml#357

deployment/ceph-ansible/ceph-osd.yaml.message: so is this CephAnsibleDisksConfig another parameter that should be added to deprecated?
i asked this on v59 but it seems it was missed. do we want to put this into deprecated too then i.e. don't use this any more it doesn't do anything

Sorry I messed with my comments: this parameter is actually still relevant for CephAnsible based deployments, because in that scenario you  can always specify (pass) a list of devices, and that's the reason is not among the list of deprecated parameters.
However, we changed the default to [] because having /dev/vdb wasn't a safe default as you don't know in advance this info from the operator's environment.
In a CephAdm based environment, for now, the OSD(s) are created using the all the available devices, so this isn't required anymore in that branch, but we're going to deprecate or remove it during the next cycle, when ceph-ansible will not be supported anymore.

Use yaml.safe_load(stream)

It can, yaml.safe_load(stream) is the equivalent of calling yaml.load(stream, Loader=yaml.SafeLoader). I021bd09d3bbc6d4b9c8965c59c7f4ec4895f8b8b was broken because it changed the function name without removing the Loader parameter.

yaml.load() without a Loader argument used to default to what is now UnsafeLoader (then just called Loader), which is why it is not recommended. (There's a new FullLoader that is now the default since 5.1.)

According to the docs BaseLoader "Only loads the most basic YAML", so it may in fact be as safe as SafeLoader. It's not clear to me why you want to limit it to that subset though.

I think secrets used by a resource should generally exist within the same namespace so that it is easier to lock down the RBAC, for example it is then possible to run the controllers consuming them using the default service account of the namespace. Thus I think it is better to not support cross namespace references for Secrets. Do you know of any use cases where we would need cross namespace references?

Tristan is right, we shouldn't base this decision on the pipeline configuration but rather on the event.

One possibility could be to judge here based on the event type. But to me this feels wrong. The skip_file_matcher switch in freezeJobGraph was only introduced by the zuul runner changes so one could freeze a job graph independently. This was done before the event was part of the item but now with this additional use case it feels like a hack.

I think it makes sense to forward the event (it is attached to the item) in 'Layout._createJobGraph' to 'Job.changeMatchesFiles' and do the filtering there based on the event or even push the event information to the matcher itself (which feels like the right place to me).

When a pipeline has both a gerrit and timer trigger, then any(filter evaluates to True. Though now that the trigger event is attached to queue items, perhaps TriggerEvent we could have a "skipFileMatcher()" procedure that could be used here.

templates/nova.conf.j2.message: this variable is now a available to override, so should be documented in defaults/main.yml for both the case when 'is mapping' is true, and not true.

Considering we defined default we can use this:

(nova_enabled_vgpu_types | map(attribute='type') | list + [discovered_vgpu_types | default('')]) | unique | join(',')

I've removed the "discovered_vgpu_types" because, from what I can tell, nova selects the first vgpu in the 'enabled_vgpu_types' list to use by default (unless there is a corresponding [vgpu_type] config option). By default this would always be the first vgpu type alphabetically. So I thought it would be best to be explicit
I'd say that default will never occur since nova_enabled_vgpu_types is defined in defaults to the empty dict. So logic is pretty tricky here

I've re-added the fallback to the discovered GPU types. I think it makes sense this way as its minimally invasive to current deployments, whilst still keeping the default present in defaults.yml and allowing people to over-ride

The 'default(blah, **true**)' should mean that the empty dictionary triggers the default due to an empty dict being false-y, as mentioned here: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_filters.html#providing-default-values. I passed it through an online jinja2 templater and it appeared to work as expected

nova/virt/hardware.py.message: True. Moved to the preceding patch

please, don't set a default parameter like this.

prefix should be None by default and then, later when looking at the argument value, if None, set it to 'hw'.

tl;dr: that's because strings are mutable and you shouldn't default parameters with mutables.
https://towardsdatascience.com/python-pitfall-mutable-default-arguments-9385e8265422

Yes, they're immutable. This is only an issue for mutable types like lists.

  >>> def foo(x=[]):
  ...     x.append('s')
  ... 
  >>> a = []
  >>> foo(a)
  >>> a
  ['s']
  >>> foo(a)
  >>> a
  ['s', 's']

The *vast* majority of the callers here use 'hw' namespace so I think a default parameter value of 'hw' is perfectly viable

Apologies if I'm getting this wrong but aren't strings immutable [1] and even if they were wouldn't this only be an issue if we were making changes to prefix as part of this method?

[1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immutable_object#Python

Shit, strings are indeed immutable so this is not an issue. Maybe just a concern about the pattern because people could copy/paste some methods without thinking whether the new arguments could be mutable. 
That's why I prefer to just have default values to be None, honestly, but that being said, now it's a nit.

zuul/zk/components.py.message: Do you have a use case in mind for a read-only ZooKeeperComponent or is this just here to make things easier extendable?

Yes, the ZooKeeperComponentRegistry#all will return ZooKeeperComponentReadOnly. The reason is that components can read other components but only the component which called the ZooKeeperComponentRegistry#register method will get a r/w access. This makes it easier to cache values (one does not have to check what is the state in ZK) and enables better prevention that a component changes attributes which it does not own.

Not sure if I like the usage of __setitem__ here. It makes using the ZooKeeperComponent a little misleading IMHO since it looks like a dict but doesn't work like a dict in all occasions (e.g. when using len() or an iterator).

I like the idea of directly updating the value of the znode when an attribute changes, but I think this could also be achieved by defining custom methods like `get()` and `set()` which don't imply any dictionary magic. IMHO this would make the usage of this class a little more explicit.

I don't see this as a blocker and leave this comment up for discussion.

Another idea would be to implement also other methods like __len__ and __iter__ to make it also work like a dict (see https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/collections.abc.html#collections-abstract-base-classes)

Can't we directly use the ZooKeeperComponenState.STOPPED here? I think if we get rid of the `.name` here we could also remove the if/else branch in the __setitem__ method checking if either the enum value or the name is provided.

This is going to be serialized to json and store in the zk node. Thats why the ".name" is needed here. The if/else in line 56 enables to use different representations of ZooKeeperComponentState. One may argue that we only need one but I left it open for the developer to decide, based on context which representation he/she wants to use.

The thing about this is that the following code fails:

  component.set('state', ZooKeeperComponentState.RUNNING)
  assert component.get('state') == ZooKeeperComponentState.RUNNING

Which is pretty counter-intuitive.  But if we retain the existing pattern that we use both for Zuul model objects as well as for ZK interaction with Nodepool, where we use string constants (improved by making them class attributes as, for example, in the Pipeline class), we can do the following:

  component.set('state', component.STATE_RUNNING)
  assert component.get('state') == component.STATE_RUNNING

That saves extra import statements in all the files that use this.  To accomplish this, we only need to do this:

  class ZooKeeperComponentReadOnly:
    STATE_RUNNING = 'running'

My preference would be to do that -- it matches the existing code, and is shorter, simpler, and has all the safety of enums (you won't accidentally set state to "RUNNNING" without causing an error) plus the advantage of input=output.

Why don't we set these values to words so it's easy to debug?

STOPPED = 'stopped'
Instead of always doing a network round trip here I think we should just catch the NoNodeError here.

sequence numer should be tracker on manila side in a thread safe manner, avoid some thread issues. The same reason as the delete fpolicy. What do you think ?!

TL;DR: I think that you are correct about race conditions between create/delete policies, since we may delete policies and let the backend incompatible with the manila configuration.

I can't see how we could track this outside the driver, because it is a share-server wide numbering, and we do not change share-server backend-details while create/deleting/managing a share. 
What we can do here would is: add a lock in driver level to avoid race conditions between fpolicy create/delete functions. 

There is a scenario that I can't think in a way to avoid concurrency issues: choose_compatible_share_server_for_share(): since at that moment the seq number may be available for a share-server (which cannot be reserved at that moment, since it is not a reservation call) and may not be available at the policy setup time.

The simple way to avoid those issues is to have a manila lock around these operations, like share replica has today, but create/manage shares don't.

I was thinking on adding a private-storage map to control this, but would add complexity to the code, and wouldn't work on DHSS=False mode, since the SVM may be shared amond other applications/users.
the fpolicy is a share server resource, I think that it would be better using the server id, given that the share can be delete afterwars and the fpolicy may still be alive, though.

We can't use share server's id since we can have multiple fpolicies inside the same SVM.
We just need to make the ID unique at this moment. The possibilities are: use the uuid from the first share that creates it or generate a new uuid. All other operations don't rely on the fpolicy itself, but on its configuration.
Another idea would be to concantenate server's id + seq number. But still, we would not use this naming logic to search for policies.
same here about the share id
Same as below.
If an error is reported here, the events will not be removed on storage side
No, they won't. The volume and other resources will remain too. The manila share will be set to 'error' and everything, including the policy, will be deleted after user requests a share-delete.

> No, they won't. The volume and other resources will remain too. The manila share will be set to 'error' and everything, including the policy, will be deleted after user requests a share-delete.

Sorry, I was to lazy to check in details that what you said is true. If one of the event, fpolicy or scope creation fails, there is no way to link the failed share to these resources, and they won't be deleted afterwards. Thanks for pointing this.

How can you ensure that any share have been applied to the fpolicy after you retrieved ?! It might end up deleting a fpolicy that have more shares on it. I think that you should track the fpolicy by server on manila side, having this resource update/delete by a lock (thread safe).
I think that a driver lock would avoid this issue, sharing the lock between create/detele operations.
if replicas can't have fpolicies, shouldn't you error out if "replication_type" extra spec is set?

this validation is in 'validate_provisioning_options_for_share', which will always be called inside '_get_provisioning_options_for_share', called in line 854. So we are safe here to continue.
Thanks for raising this question.

consider using the similar synchronizer from the coordination module - this rudimentary file lock does not support distributed locking - the one from the coordination module also defaults to file locks and provides a 1-1 compatibility, but, if deployers choose, they can use a DLM via tooz.

same concurrent problem: you may report here that fpolicy is lower than limit. After, other thread creates the last one, than when the code reaches the fpolicy creation step it wont have enough space and might not reuse the 10 policies. It may be tracked by the manila in a thread safe manner.

I think that this scenario should be solved by an external lock, managed by the manila itself. It is really hard to manage this resources here since we shouldn't do any reservation at this moment. So, anything could happend between 'choose_share_server_compatible_with_share' and the share creation/manage moment. zuul/driver/github/githubconnection.py.message:
This will have a bad effect on loading performance with many projects and many branches. E.g. in our deployment this will create hundreds to thousands of additional requests during startup or reconfiguration.

Can you double check (maybe post an example request) that this returns the protection information? If yes we should think about whether it makes sense to query first with the protected flag and if that doesn't work fall back to this approach.
This still causes one extra request per project in the normal case. I think it's possible to do this fallback directly in the while loop (see below).

Something like this here:

 if params['protected'] and resp.status_code == 404:
     params['protected'] = 0
     resp = github.session.get(...)
     url = resp.links.get(...)

I'd find it much easier to read if we structure it like this:

  while url:
      resp = github.session.get(
          url, headers=headers, params=params)


      if resp.status_code == 403:
          self.log.error(str(resp))
          rate_limit = github.rate_limit()
          if rate_limit['resources']['core']['remaining'] == 0:
              self.log.warning(
                  "Rate limit exceeded, using empty branch list")
          return []


      # NOTES: If we set protected=1 to list branched, but no
      # repository admin permission, github API will raise 404 so we try
      # again with no filter and filter ourselve.
      if resp.status_code == 404 and params['protected']:
          params['protected'] = 0
          resp = github.session.get(
              url, headers=headers, params=params)


      # Fall back to use combo querying to get protected branches.
      if exclude_unprotected and params['protected'] == 0:
          for branch in resp.json():
              detail = self.getBranch(project.name, branch['name'])
              if detail and detail['protected']:
                  branches.append(branch['name'])
      else:
          branches.extend([x['name'] for x in resp.json()])


      # check if we need to do further paged calls
      url = resp.links.get('next', {}).get('url')

tripleoclient/config/undercloud.py.message: nit, any reason we don't set this as the default and just do "env_data['PublicTLSCAFile'] = CONF.undercloud_ca_cert_file" in the other file?

This is a good question, and I want to explain more clearly what the current options are - and what this parameter will allow us to do.

The current code allows one to do the following:

1. provide a service cert.  This cert is expected to be trusted, so there needs to be some out of band method to provide the CA cert on the box.  The way to do this is to specify undercloud_service_certificate

2. generate a service certificate using certmonger.  This adds the template environments/public-tls-undercloud.yaml which defines PublicTLSCAFile and InternalTLSCAFile to be /etc/pki/ca-trust/source/anchors/cm-local-ca.pem .  We do this by specifying generate_service_certificate and leaving certificate_generation_ca = local

3.  Use no tls cert - which adds environments/ssl/no-tls-endpoints-public-ip.yaml.  o do this, do not specify undercloud_service_certificate or generate_service_certificate

Two new scenarios can be supported by this new parameter:

4.  generate a service certificate using IPA.  This requires generate_service_certificate and certificate_generation_ca = IPA.  This was broken because the templates would specify the PublicTLSCAFile and InternalTLSCAFile to the certmonger CA cert.  Instead we can set these using the new parameter.

5. provide a service cert and also a CA cert file location so that we don't have to have it set up to be trusted ahead of time.  Of course, you'd still have to get the ca cert file on the box to begin with so ..  maybe this really isn't that useful.

Hmm, maybe the better way to do this is to simply trigger off the certificate_generation_ca and just set the certs accordingly.  Or we could just tell folks to override PublicTLSCAFile and  InternalTLSCAFile

You'll need to microversion this change. Here's an example of how that's done: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/manila/+/755666

Consumers of the manila API at a particular microversion are given the contract that the API schema/behavior will not change, and all new changes will come with a new microversion. So, when you add a microversion around this change, you will also need to add unit test cases to ascertain that the previous behavior is maintained, and that the schema change that you're introducing is only made in the newer microversion. The theory of microversions is here: https://docs.openstack.org/manila/latest/contributor/api_microversion_dev.html

I believe this is suppose to be an underscore (_).

Nope! AWS drops any header with '=' in it -- but it *will* faithfully preserve '_' in user meta.

Swift, on the other hand, "allows" '_' but translates them to '-' -- as best I can tell this wasn't a conscious design decision, just an artifact of being a WSGI app and inheriting all that CGI baggage. We *do* allow '=', though, so we can use that to encode a '='. And since we've found one case where we need to encode something funky, I assumed we may find others so I didn't do it as a simple replacement. See https://github.com/openstack-archive/swift3/commit/f3a933aad1f29a90bd2dbbabe24bf7d1b62ede9b if you're interested in some of the history.

IIRC, this comment made more sense as it currently is in an earlier iteration -- it used to be that each test was a tuple of [label, request-setup-func, resp-check-func]. Now it's [label, promise] so we can arbitrarily chain requests and more easily make a group of tests conditional on some other thing (like SLO, DLO, and symlink tests all looking at a single /info response).

The assertions I'm most interested in are all quite low-level, though, so I think it still makes sense to use raw XMLHttpRequests and inspect the results ourselves (rather than let aws-sdk-js hand us back some S3Response object).

I'm not sure I understand the flow here.

We return a promise - that will (when resolved?) hijack the send listener and call a closure over the resolve inline - in which we pass it another MakeRequest promise...

Yep, so we make a new promise (which can start executing any time between when it's created and when something tries to resolve it). Inside that promise, we make a new S3 request, prevent it from actually kicking off the request itself, add a new send listener, and then "send" it. Instead of aws-sdk-js sending the request, we get all the signing details and headers, filter a few out (I think they caused some spurious warnings in my browser console? or worse, prevented presigned GETs from being treated as a "simple" request) and use the same request-response-promise stuff all the other tests use.

The new promise eventually resolves to the result of the MakeRequest that has all the auth details.

I'm tempted to say we skip opening in the new -- I'm not actually sure corruption matters as long as we compare inodes in stat results. For any given filename in the new, either

* there's no such file in the old,
* there's a hardlink to the same inode in the old, or
* the same filename exists in the old but as some other file.

For the first two, corruption's moot -- we don't have a good copy to go back to. For the last, we can't resolve the state anyway and need to bring it to the operator's attention.
Plus, this is another opportunity for things to get cleaned up... meaning our file lists are out of date.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/api/controll.message:
Will the extract_tarfile above will work fine without the chmod being placed before it?
Also,  CONFIG_FILE_PERMISSION_DEFAULT  is 644 and app_path is a directory isn't it?
Why not do this where the directory is created (in TempDirectory function) on the directory itself. That is what the existing functionality was doing.
Do we actually need the chmod? mkdtemp creates a temp directory with 600?

Umask is used to set the initial file permissions when the file/directory is created whereas chmod is used to change the file permissions after the file/directory is created. Looks like python tempfile does not let you pass in the mode so in order to retain the original permissions (600) you will need to use chmod. By default it's created with 700 permissions.
I would move this line up to 158.

This is a directory.  Therefore if you make it 600 permissions, you cannot create anything inside it. directories need executable permissions.

Sample program to illustrate the problem.  (Just run this.   the permissions need to be 0x700) unless something else is controlling the permissions for the folder.


from contextlib import contextmanager
import tempfile
import os
import shutil

@contextmanager
def TempDirectory():
    tmpdir = tempfile.mkdtemp()
    os.chmod(tmpdir, 0o600)
    try:
        yield tmpdir
    finally:
        shutil.rmtree(tmpdir)


with TempDirectory() as app_path:
    bar = app_path + "/some_file.txt"
    print(bar)
    with open(bar, 'w') as f:
        f.write("some data")
        f.flush()

I missed this previously. In a RESTful API, a fetch/get/show operation fetches an individual resource or record and typically looks like this:

  GET /resources/{id}

By comparison, a list operation typically looks like this:

  GET /resources

By configuring 'allow_fetch = True' and not setting anything else, you've indicated that you're only able to support the former and not the latter (nor updating, creating or deleting, for that matter). Does this seem correct to you? Hint: look at the URLs you'd be using with this. The unit tests in Cinder have some hints...

Also note that 'resource_key' (singular) is used to remove the envelope or wrapping around responses for operations that involved working with an individual resource: creating, deleting, updating or fetching. 'resources_key' (plural) is used to do the same for operations that involve multiple resource, so listing. Given you've only specified 'allow_fetch', you don't need 'resources_key' since you'll never be listing anything. However, if you were to change this so that only 'allow_list = True', then you shouldn't specify 'resource_key'.

It seems to me still after looking at multiple sources that the only capability that should be allowed is fetch. After looking through examples on the v3 block storage API,[1], I agree with your comment about how the operations typically look. However, it still looks as though the Limit class should only support the fetch operation.
First, if we look here https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html#limits-limits, although it looks like a list operation, it describes it as a fetch operation.
Secondly, if we look at [2], the compute limit only supports the fetch operation.

As for your comment about "resource_key" and "resources_key", I agree that we don't need "resources_key."

Also, upon a closer look, I believe that the "resource_key" should be equal to "limits" and not "limit". It wouldn't make sense after looking at both [1] and [2].

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/src/branch/master/openstack/compute/v2/_proxy.py

Dockerfile.message:
I'm pretty sure this "yum install" will falsely succeed if mirror doesn't respond at all. The "skip_missing_names_on_install=0" earlier only catches the case when the mirror responds with HTTP 401 or similar, not when the mirror is not reachable at all.

So the check /var/lib/mock would normally fail in thus case, but not now that it is conditional.

Suggest to add an "rpm -q mock && rm -q mock-core-configs" somewhere after "yum install".

You are right.  The issue is with the docker cache. It has cached a layer where the yum install passed even though http://mirror.starlingx.cengn.ca/mirror/centos/epel/dl.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel/7/x86_64/Packages/m/mock-1.4.16-1.el7.noarch.rpm failed.  

Someone must have polluted the cache by by using the dockerfile prior to Davlet's "Dockerfile: fail in "yum install" on missing packages" fix, and having the bad luck to catch cengn down.

I think I need to alter the yum install line so that http://mirror.starlingx.cengn.ca/mirror/centos/epel/dl.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel/7/x86_64/Packages/m/mock-1.4.16-1.el7.noarch.rpm is installed independently of the rest.  In that way, even a broken cache from an old build won't kill new builds.
Come to think of it, why wouldn't /var/lib/mock exist? We are installing an exact version of mock that contains it, no?
"rm -rf /var/lib/mock" would also work, and would handle the case where this dir is somehow non-empty (which presumably couldn't happen)

build-tools/build-rpms-parallel.message: I'm not going to pretend to fully understand what's happening with all this. Is this share factor constantly adjusting? Or does the first build launched get the biggest share?

share_factor is an estimate of the number of builds we might asked to do in parallel.  Resources allocated is potentially 1/share_factor, but is subject to other maximums.

Initial estimate for the share_factor is square root of number of users. but we may skew that if there are already builds running.

Yes, the algorithm will give a new build significantly fewer resources if the number of active builds is >= the ideal share factor.  Potentially dropping him down to 1 worker and/or no ramdisks.

devstack/lib/ceph.message: Won't we now need to override this to nautilus in jobs for stable/ussuri and older; or we could start seeing some unusual failures there?
Yes, that's why we keep two different releases. Explained below :)
Yeah, that is possible because this repo is branchless.

IIUC, this variable is here so that you can automatically fall back to an older release of ceph when running on Ubuntu Xenial. 

Is this needed any longer? I remember you needed this when download.ceph.com didn't have Xenial builds for some of the versions we wanted to test (nautilus at that time). But now they seem to do: http://download.ceph.com/debian-octopus/dists/xenial/

Can we just delete this "CEPH_RELEASE_STABLE" option altogether and just work with "CEPH_RELEASE"?
Always good to learn how it was supposed to be. 😊

We were keeping this for stable jobs. If Xenial, then we set up this version. If Bionic or Focal, then we set up CEPH_RELEASE. IMHO the suggested approach is better. Let's override CEPH_RELEASE on the stable jobs and unify this.

FWIW this is breaking nova-grenade-multinode on stable/train and devstack-plugin-ceph-tempest (non-voting) on stable/stein [2] as it's still based on py2. The Octopus release doesn't provide any py2 libs so n-cpu fails to start.

I appreciate that this is because Nova is abusing the plugin by checking it out outside the control of Zuul etc so I'm working to pin it to the original nautilus release in I1d029ebe78b16ed2d4345201b515baf3701533d5 ahead of dropping the hooks entirely in I02b2b851a74f24816d2f782a66d94de81ee527b0 finally.

[1] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/builds?job_name=nova-grenade-multinode&project=openstack%2Fnova&branch=stable%2Ftrain
[3] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/builds?job_name=devstack-plugin-ceph-tempest&project=openstack%2Fnova&branch=stable%2Fstein

> FWIW this is breaking nova-grenade-multinode on stable/train and devstack-plugin-ceph-tempest (non-voting) on stable/stein [2] as it's still based on py2. The Octopus release doesn't provide any py2 libs so n-cpu fails to start.

Just to correct myself there, devstack-plugin-ceph-tempest is pinned via the job definition in the plugin to nautilus so I'm not sure why that's actually failing.

ovn_octavia_provider/tests/functional/te.message:
I guess these tests could be broken into one helper method passing the protocol as a parameter. That would make it easy to add new protocols to be tested in the future. For example:

 def _test_listener(self, protocol, port):
   lb_data = self._create_load_balancer_and_validate(
        {'vip_network': 'vip_network',
         'cidr': '10.0.0.0/24'})
   self._create_pool_and_validate(lb_data, "test_pool", protocol=protocol)
   pool_id = lb_data['pools'][0].pool_id

   # Create member in the pool
   self._create_member_and_validate(
       lb_data, pool_id, lb_data['vip_net_info'][1],
       lb_data['vip_net_info'][0], '10.0.0.4')
   self._create_member_and_validate(lb_data, pool_id,
                                    net_info[1], net_info[0], '20.0.0.4')

    ... <and so on>

 def test_listener_tcp(self):
     self._test_listener('TCP', 80)

 def test_listener_udp(self):
     self._test_listener('UDP', 53)

 def test_listener_sctp(self):
     self._test_listener('SCTP', 8081)
Yes,  that would be a good cleanup, I'll put it on the list for Xena.

doc/requirements.txt.message: I always had a question while going through the patches like update requirements, On what basis this versions are updated.

That is a very good question.  For this one, I just noticed that there is a big gap between what we had here and what we're using in the other cinder projects, so I updated it.  But the general idea is that the CI testing is being run with 3.5.1 right now (as indicated by pip freeze output), so we really don't know any more if the older versions work.

lower-constraints.txt.message: I could see more requirements are removed, any reason for removing this requirements.

Another good question.  The community has decided to include only direct dependencies in this file, where these are:

* what's in requirements.txt
* what's in test-requirements.txt
* what's in 'extras' in setup.cfg

more info is in this thread: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-February/020556.html

zuul/executor/common.py.message: Shouldn't this be undone in the "Separate out executor server from runner" patch?
Yes, but because it was already copied over I left it for now to make reviewing between diffs easier (in theory). If people want it moved back we can.
Honestly, everything in this class just seems like something that should be (and is!) on the AnsibleJob classs.  The extra layer is more typing and more confusion when trying to follow the code.

So in the case of the executor server we need to do some gearman commands in these steps. Thus they can't be in a general AnsibleJob class. These could be abstract methods on the AnsibleJob though that the ExecutorAnsibleJob would then inherit from and implement.

That would be a similar outcome, but given the previous feedback I was looking to avoid it. However, the implementation due to complexities ended up coming back to a base class-like structure as I worked through the refactor.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Could we indicate that this adds this feature?

    Add export system configuration

I have a couple of suggestions:

Let us describe export system configuration as a Dell EMC iDRAC OEM action.
How about defining or describing target? Presently, I have no idea what it is referring to.

I recommend the following resources for writing quality Git commit messages, in priority order, with the first one having the highest priority.

1. https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages
2. https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/#imperative

sushy_oem_idrac/__init__.py.message: don't include for now - leave the file empty as before (revert)

sushy_oem_idrac/resources/constants.py.message: maybe in the end this file is not necessary. In given example in sushy there are high level constants that are shared among many resources where under resource folder (e.g., management) there were resource-specific constants. In this case these constants are not generic to be used in different resources, in the end there should be management constants like EXPORT_ALL_CONFIG used and exposed. @Richard can you clarify?

This is Dell specific, while all others are vendor independent.
Suggest we break them into vendor independent and vendor dependent categories.
And define rules on how to add vendor dependent exports.

sushy_oem_idrac/resources/manager/manage.message: Let's explain what this "export" operation does and why is it needed. Reading the code I got no clue.
Should we have some log message confirming the outcome of this operation?

Can input value be validated before it makes the call?
Or will it raise error if invalid option provided? What type of error?
Should these be pre-defined or based on actual values at `Target@Redfish.AllowableValues` in Redfish resource?

It will raise an error if we pass an invalid option.
Error Type: BadRequestError
Brief Error: Unable to run the method because an invalid FQDD is entered
Yes Aija, these values are based on actual values at `Target@Redfish.AllowableValues` in redfish resource.

I guess this is not clear from the comment. The comment reads like the only options are ALL, BIOS, IDRAC, NIC, RAID, but based on the system it can be different. Maybe mention that actual values depend on the system (found in Target.AllowableValues) and give these just as an example?
Where/When does it raise these errors?

InvalidParameterValue - above it says that it will return BadRequestError for invalid option (target). Can it be clarified which one is returned if passing incorrect target?
(And what happens when invalid ExportFormat is passed?)

InvalidParameterValue: We get this error when we pass an invalid target

ExtensionError: Will remove this error.
Was it requirement to hardcode this to "XML"? Could this be parameter based on available options?
Since it would be easy to add a parameter to support other formats such as JSON and default it to XML at some point in the future, let's leave it as-is for now.

Might be handy that Ironic defines what format it will be returned so it does not have to rely on internals of this function. Also if in future smbdy starting to need to get JSON, then Ironic wouldn't require changes to keep using XML. Just my thoughts.
Current implementation in IRonic is based on XML lib, so let's keep it as it for now.
@Mahendra - please keep BadRequestError as it doesn't need ServerSideError
How is this related? Perhaps this sentence can be removed.
Component of the system to export the configuration from. Can be the entire system.
What is the format of the return value? Is there public, on-line documentation of it which can be referenced?

> What is the format of the return value? Is there public, on-line
 > documentation of it which can be referenced?

We can specify the format of the return value to JSON or XML and we specified XML format in action_data.
Ref link: [Content No 5 A.2]
https://downloads.dell.com/manuals/all-products/esuprt_solutions_int/esuprt_solutions_int_solutions_resources/dell-management-solution-resources_white-papers15_en-us.pdf
I believe the parentheses are unnecessary.

The values for 'target' should be represented by constants, instead of arbitrary string literals. There is a pattern established in sushy that I think we should follow. Please see the following:

Declaration of sushy 'Manager' 'reset()' method 'value' parameter value constants:
1. Common sushy resource constants, which can be leveraged by specific resources, such as 'Manager': https://github.com/openstack/sushy/blob/ee85feda89026875296c0be763e045e25641d6a0/sushy/resources/constants.py#L90-L118
2. sushy 'Manager' resource constants: https://github.com/openstack/sushy/blob/ee85feda89026875296c0be763e045e25641d6a0/sushy/resources/manager/constants.py#L18-L24
3. Publication of sushy constants to code consuming sushy. Note that such consumers should not reach into the internal implementation of sushy by importing the internal modules which declare them. Instead, they can reference them like so:

    sushy.RESET_MANAGER_GRACEFUL_RESTART

See https://github.com/openstack/sushy/blob/master/sushy/__init__.py


Mappings from Redfish resource reset-related action constants to sushy constants and reverse mappings of the same:
1.Common Redfish constant mappings: https://github.com/openstack/sushy/blob/ee85feda89026875296c0be763e045e25641d6a0/sushy/resources/mappings.py#L67-L79
2. sushy 'Manager' resource constant mappings: https://github.com/openstack/sushy/blob/ee85feda89026875296c0be763e045e25641d6a0/sushy/resources/manager/mappings.py#L17-L22

The argument value should be validated against the values allowed by the service, and, if valid, converted from a sushy constant to a Redfish constant. Here is an example: https://github.com/openstack/sushy/blob/ee85feda89026875296c0be763e045e25641d6a0/sushy/resources/manager/manager.py#L183-L188.
Are there unit tests added for this method?

Is there an example of Dell system that does not have these values provided?
Then better return empty list instead of all theoretically possible values. Otherwise consumer will not be able to distinguish when these are really supported and when couldn't find out. If empty list is returned, then consumer can deal with it in way it decides to.
Thanks Aija for giving direction for fetching the values from the correct field. I was extracting allowed values from the different fields, that's why I was getting an empty list.
update this comment saying that valid values can be get from `get_allowed_export_system_config_values` and what constants can be used as input params.

thanks, that was not meant to be precise text for the docstring. I meant to say that this needs documenting what constants exactly can be used otherwise it's not obvious. From my understanding consumer can use EXPORT_ALL, EXPORT_BIOS, etc. while they are supported by target system.

So the part that starts with "valid values can be.. " could be replaced with:

"Valid values can be get from `get_allowed_export_system_config_values` and correspond to EXPORT_* constants."

as discussed in the meeting, let's make this function private (rename to _export_system_configuration) as currently it will be used only from this library in the followup patch.

(I'll work on public method in my patches.)

remove 'and correspond
            to EXPORT_ALL, EXPORT_NIC, EXPORT_RAID, EXPORT_BIOS, EXPORT_BIOS
            and EXPORT_IDRAC constants'

common/deploy-steps.j2.message:
It seems we want tasks in deployments.yaml to run before network configuration (with reasoning that people may be using those to configure network per-requisites). I had earlier moved it after network config[1], but was reverted by Alex.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/749432/2/common/deploy-steps.j2#535

The problem is that we mixed up PreNetworkConfig, which is supposed to run before network configurations, and ExtraConfigPre, which WAS supposed to run AFTER network configurations.
We should split these to and run PreNetworkConfig only before applying network configurations.

deliverables/wallaby/tripleo-heat-templa.message:
LGTM. "Replacing" is the right word. Extra details in pending release notes [1]

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/767294/61/releasenotes/notes/cephadm-28185ca8ac814567.yaml

Can't we capitalize this one too?

At first glance with a lower letters it could be interpreted as a typo

Better "FRR" or the long form "FFRouting" (https://frrouting.org/).

But... the FRR THT service patch hasn't merged yet so technically one can't yet deploy with FRR enabled.

https://review.opendev.org/q/topic:bgpsupport
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/763657

ack changed to FRRouter

WRT the deadline, ... deadline for this review is this friday i believe

WRT 'when is wallaby' ... it is in ~1 month for OpenStack https://releases.openstack.org/wallaby/schedule.html#w-final

BUT it will be in about 1.5 maybe up to 2 months for us/tripleo.

I massaged the words a bit aded 'Early (beta) support for...'

WDYT? if you think there is a high chance that you won't get the tripleo-heat-templates patches in by then, perhaps we will consider removing this but i think it should be doable in the above timeframe?

I should have added a big thank you for considering the FRR work worth of being featured in the TripleO highlight list!

The THT service may be available for Wallaby GA release. We've been testing it daily in the past weeks. Is there a deadline for getting this patch in?

Ceph version upgraded to Octopus. cephadm may be used to deploy/maintain a Ceph RBD cluster but not all Ceph services (e.g. RGW). ceph-ansible may still be used to deploy/maintain all Ceph services but will be replaced with cephadm in next release.

Something to keep in mind for future highlights - what does this mean for end users? These highlights are to communicate high level useful things to the marketing folks to tell users why they would want to update to this release. This seems like a low level, release note type of thing. As a user of TripleO, I don't know what this would mean to me.

OK, great. Then maybe it would be worth a follow up here to change this to something like:

"Users are now able to create networks and ports directly via the API, without the need to create or update using Heat"

Not saying you need to change anything, but I think that might make it more clear what message we're trying to get out.

Thanks!

ack thanks for the feedback and yeah I get your point and probably illustrates itself here. You have the impression that it is a low level thing but in fact it isn't.
This one allows users to create the required networks and ports outside of the heat stack create/update that is traditionally where this was done. So it does have a big impact hopefully positive in making it easier to create and maintain these resources.
